Award.AwardTitle: Large-scale Terrane Displacement in the Arctic: Evidence from Faults in the Northern Yukon
Award.AbstractNarration:
The shapes of the continents are modified over time by a variety of tectonic processes including large-scale horizontal transport of crustal fragments. This project explores the idea that this process was important in shaping the current configuration of the North American Arctic region. The research team will investigate a major fault system - the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system - in northern Yukon, Canada to determine if it accommodated horizontal movement of a large portion of the Arctic region and, if so, when this occurred. This research project will not only further our understanding of large-scale transport of crustal fragments along continent-scale strike-slip systems, but also provide new insights into the tectonic evolution of the poorly understood Arctic region of North America, a region important for its natural resources. The study will promote international collaboration between academic researchers at two U.S. institutions, two Canadian and German universities, and government research agencies in both Germany, Canada, and the United States. The collaborative international effort will also generate research opportunities and training for undergraduate and graduate students at both Dartmouth College and the University of Iowa, as well as a series of public lectures and a new museum exhibit in the Upper Valley of New England.

Recent models for the Paleozoic tectonic evolution of the Arctic highlight significant, yet poorly understood, margin-parallel transport of crustal fragments relative to the North American craton; however, very little is known about the hypothetical structures that accommodated these displacements. The goal of this research project is to study the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system of Yukon, Canada, a craton-bounding structure that potentially accommodated the displacement of Arctic Alaska and other Arctic terranes across the northern margin of Laurentia. The fault system was probably reactivated during the Mesozoic and Tertiary, but may be a much older early Paleozoic structure. The research team aims to determine if the structure separates geologic units with different histories and paleogeographic origins and if there is any evidence for Paleozoic displacement on the structure. This project will involve: 1) development of a large, stratigraphically-constrained provenance data set, consisting of sandstone petrography, large-N detrital zircon U/Pb geochronology and hafnium isotopes, and major and trace element geochemistry and neodymium isotopes on mudstone, from previously collected and new samples of late Neoproterozoic-Silurian strata in the North Slope subterrane and Yukon block of northwestern Canada; and 2) a detailed structural and geochronological examination of the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system in northern Yukon, Canada. This multidisciplinary project will fundamentally inform tectonic models for the evolution of the Arctic and northwestern margin of North America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on studying a poorly understood fault system exposed along the Alaska-Yukon border region, which we refer to herein as the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system. More specifically, we focused on examining sedimentary and volcanic rocks exposed northwest and southeast of the fault system, the former of which belong to an exotic piece of crust called the Arctic Alaska terrane and the latter of which represent classically-defined North American crust. As a part of this project, we attempted to define the origin and reconstruct the displacement history of the Arctic Alaska terrane through integrated stratigraphic, paleontological, geochronological, and geochemical analyses from rocks spanning the Neoproterozoic (ca. 1000–541 million years ago) to Devonian (ca. 419–359 million years ago). In addition, we coupled detailed geological mapping with abundant structural measurements and geochronological/geochemical analyses from samples within the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system in order to understand the displacement history and kinematics of the major faults that are exposed at the surface today. This work was conducted over three separate field seasons (2016-2018) in Alaska and Yukon, Canada, and it involved three graduate and seven undergraduate students from Dartmouth College, as well as one graduate and multiple undergraduate students from the University of Iowa.

The primary research outcomes of the work conducted at Dartmouth College in collaboration with researchers at the University of Iowa include:

1) The North Slope subterrane of Arctic Alaska originated on or near the northeastern Arctic margin of North America in proximity to Greenland and Ellesmere Island, Canada. These rocks share remarkable similarities with strata of the Franklinian Basin, and were most likely deposited along the northern passive margin of North American prior to their deformation during the Ordovician–Carboniferous.

2) The Apoon assemblage of the Arctic Alaska terrane represents a juvenile Ordovician–Devonian(?) island arc complex (Doonerak arc complex) that most likely originated in a similar tectonic setting to the Taconic–Caledonian arc system of northeastern Laurentia and Baltica. This arc complex shares affinities with other exotic terranes within the North American Cordillera, such as the Alexander terrane.

3) The Arctic Alaska terrane was most likely assembled from multiple peri-Laurentian and peri-Baltic crustal fragments outboard of the northeastern margin of Laurentian in the middle Paleozoic, during or prior to translation of terranes across the northern margin of North America.

4) The Kaltag-Porcupine fault system juxtaposes polydeformed rocks of the Arctic Alaska terrane with low-grade Mesoproterozoic–Paleozoic rocks of the Yukon block, a distinct component of the northwestern North American continent. This fault system most likely represents a long-lived major crustal boundary that was reactivated multiple times throughout the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic eras. As a result, it must play a major, yet underappreciated, role in our understanding of the tectonic development of the circum-Arctic region.

This project has provided significant opportunities in training and education for our burgeoning STEM workforce. Dartmouth College personnel supported by the project include one MSc student (Virginia Wala), two PhD students (James Busch and Karol Faehnrich), and seven undergraduates (Peter Mamrol, Josh Perez, Caleb Town, Joe Malinowski, Jack Taylor, Charlotte Nutt, and Maxwell Saylor). Collaboration with field and geochronologic research of MSc student Matthew Trembath (University of Iowa) has also been provided by this project. The project has also contributed to the development of international collaborations between several academic institutions (Dartmouth College, University of Iowa, McGill University) and two government agencies (Bundesanstalt fur Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe (BGR) and Yukon Geological Survey). In addition, it has supported the installation of a new museum exhibit on Arctic Geology at Dartmouth College, as well as multiple public lectures about Arctic resources and geosciences at both Dartmouth and the University of Iowa. This project has supported the publication of a new Geological Society of America Special Paper volume, over eleven  peer-reviewed manuscripts, twenty public presentations at conferences, and at least six undergraduate senior thesis dissertations. In addition, this project facilitated the organization of three separate dedicated sessions at annual geoscience meetings, and it provided key course material for hundreds of students at Dartmouth College and the University of Iowa.
